org.lucidfox.jpromises.core

Class Promise<V>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.lucidfox.jpromises.core.Promise<V>
  • Type Parameters:
    V - the value type
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Thenable<V>

    @GwtCompatible
public final class Promise<V>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Thenable<V>

    The core class of the JPromises library.

    Promise is a concrete implementation of Thenable that represents a value to be computed later.

    A Promise is instantiated with a PromiseHandler, which computes the value and sets the promise into either the resolved or rejected state. Further attempts to change the promise's state will throw IllegalStateException.

    Once a promise is either resolved or rejected, it will chain to all resolve or reject callbacks added by then, in the same order in which then is called. For each call to then, either the resolved callback is called if the promise was resolved (with the promise's resolved value), or the rejected callback is called if the promise was rejected (with the promise's rejection reason).

    If the callback returns a promise, then the promise previously returned by then is chained after the promise returned by the callback, using its then method, and resolved/rejected with that promise's result or reject reason, respectively. Otherwise, the promise previously returned by then is either resolved with null, or rejected with the current promise's reject reason, depending on the current promise's state.

    (Note that resolving the promise returned by then with null goes against the JavaScript Promises/A+ specification. In Java's typesafe world, it is necessary because, generally speaking, the returned promise may have a different value type compared to the current promise. If you want to work with a meaningful value in the chained promise, pass it a meaningful value through the resolved callback, perhaps using PromiseFactory.resolve(V).)

    Callbacks passed via then are guaranteed to be invoked asynchronously, as defined by the promise factory's specified deferred invoker. In practice, this usually means they are invoked after all pending events in the application's event loop are processed.

    This class is thread-safe. Objects passed to the PromiseHandler or then(org.lucidfox.jpromises.core.ResolveCallback<? super V, R>, org.lucidfox.jpromises.core.RejectCallback<R>) can be called from any thread without corrupting the promise's state.

    • Method Detail

      • then

        public <R> Promise<R> then(ResolveCallback<? super V,R> onResolve,
                           RejectCallback<R> onReject)

        Specifies code to be run after the promise is resolved (either to a value, or a rejection exception).

        After the callbacks are registered using then, if the promise's computation completes successfully, it calls onResolve with the computed value. If it fails, it calls onReject with the rejection reason (exception). Only one of these callbacks is called, and only once.

        If either callback is null, or returns a null promise, the thenable returned by the method is in turn resolved or rejected, depending on whether this promise was resolved or rejected. If a valid promise was returned, the promise returned by this method is chained after the thenable returned by the callback.

        This implementation throws no exceptions. Any exceptions are passed by rejecting the returned promise. Additionally, any exception thrown during execution of onResolve or onReject causes the resulting promise to be rejected with that exception.

        Specified by:
        then in interface Thenable<V>
        Type Parameters:
        R - the value type of the result promise
        Parameters:
        onResolve - the resolve callback (optional)
        onReject - the reject callback (optional)
        Returns:
        a Promise that is chained after the current promise

      • then

        public Promise<java.lang.Void> then(VoidResolveCallback<? super V> onResolve,
                                    VoidRejectCallback onReject)
        Convenience method. Works like the regular then method, except the callbacks passed to it cannot return a promise. It works as if a return null was appended to onResolve and onReject, which causes the promise to return a new Promise<Void> that is resolved to null after the current promise is resolved.
        Parameters:
        onResolve - the resolve callback (optional)
        onReject - the reject callback (optional)
        Returns:
        a Promise that is chained after the current promise
        See Also:
        then(ResolveCallback,RejectCallback)

      • done

        public void done(VoidResolveCallback<? super V> onResolve,
                 VoidRejectCallback onReject)
        Convenience method. Works like the regular then method, except the callbacks passed to it cannot return a promise. It works as if a return null was appended to onResolve and onReject. No new promise is returned, and this method is intended to be the last in a chain of then calls.
        Parameters:
        onResolve - the resolve callback (optional)
        onReject - the reject callback (optional)
        See Also:
        then(ResolveCallback,RejectCallback)

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()

        Returns the string representation of this promise.

        It is only intended for debugging purposes, so the format is not fixed. However, the following may be regarded as typical:

        • Promise (pending)
        • Promise (resolved, value = 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z)
        • Promise (rejected, exception = java.lang.ArithmeticException: / by zero)

        The state of the promise is, at this time, intentionally not exposed via the public API, though it may be in the future. Do not parse the output of this method to find the promise state programmatically.

        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
